Such populations are referred to as "sibling species." By this definition of species there are over 6000 species of fruit flies (Drosophila) in Hawaii alone!  It can be confusing to those who are inadequately educated in the issues at hand. The word has at least three meanings in evolutionary biology. 
 
 One is the definition. I learned that evolution is a change in the frequency of alleles in a population over time. But I have seen other biologists take exception to this definition as too narrow and not encompassing all of evolution. For example, polyploidy events are fairly common in plants, and while the relative frequencies of the alleles hasn't changed, I can't think of a biologist who would reject this as evolution. Perhaps we should define evolution as a change in the genetic makeup of a population over time.
 
 Another use of the word is in reference to the observations of events that fit the definition. The observed changes in the peppered moth is an example of such events. It is evolution because the change is caused by changes in the genetic makeup of the population over time.
 
 Finally, there is the theories. Even though it is used in the singular, "evolutionary theory", the theory of evolution is really many theories that explain many facets of a complex subject. Each of these theories have to stand or fall on its own merit. It is possible to falsify a theory of evolution without casting any doubt on the larger, overall body of knowledge.
 
 By the way, Ernst Mayr dicerns 5 separate theories that Darwin stated in On the Origin of Species, each of which may be accepted or rejected independant of the others. Each has been tested and verified.
 
Do you think evolution is over used? We could talk about the evolution of art, as an example, but the process has nothing to do with 'eye evolution'

 Yes. But the word had meaning outside of biology first. Often existing words are used in science but are assigned specific, limited meanings. Outside of biological science, the word doesn't refer to the theories of evolution. The word means change. In Darwin's day it even carried the implication that it was progress. That's why Darwin didn't like it applied to his theories. So biology can't demand that everyone stop using the word outside of biology. It is legitimate to talk of the evolution or the universe, or stelar evolution, or the evolution of art or music. Things change. But the theory of evolution refers to specific kinds of change in living organisms, as above. Moreover, there is no implication in progress, or increase in complexity, required increase in information, or new species.
